units.text: Learning Objectives
By the end of this module, Election Judges will know the cyber, insider (i.e., human), and physical threats that may occur during the mail-in voting process and how they can be mitigated.

Mail-in voting has been used in the United States, in some form, since the mid-1800s; however, this does not mean that it is free from the potential for errors. Just like any other way to cast a ballot, mail-in voting is vulnerable to threats.

To ensure that the process is carried out as successfully as possible, it is the Election Judge’s responsibility to be aware of the cyber, insider (i.e., human), and physical threats that may arise when voting by mail. By doing so, we can preserve the integrity and security of our elections.
In this section, we will discuss the possible physical threats that may need to be mitigated to secure the mail-in voting process when a voter chooses to mail their ballot.

Mail-in voting is an alternative for those who may not want to, or are unable to, vote in person. Elections Officials, County employees, and/or Small Business Enterprises deliver mail ballots to voters. In Maryland, the State Board office contracts with a vendor who has been certified to print official ballots.
The following are physical threats related to mailing the ballot:

items: An individual may steal a blank ballot from a mailbox and use it to vote.
An individual may acquire access to a drop box and alter markings on ballots or remove them.
An individual may physically damage or destroy mailboxes or drop boxes.
A ballot is accidentally or intentionally lost through the mail.
Mail transit may be delayed due to unforeseen reasons.

units.text: A voter may discover that their ballot has been affected by one of these threats by checking the status of their ballot through an online portal (if one is available in their district) or by being contacted by Election Officials via text, email, or phone call. If their ballot has been affected, they can initiate the ballot cure process to request a replacement.

To do so, they must contact their local Board of Elections. A replacement will be produced with a new barcode generated by the Voter Registration system. Once the voter receives the replacement, they should fill it out and return it. If the first mail ballot is returned and its barcode is scanned, the system will reject it.

Local Boards of Elections have deadlines for sending and receiving mail. Whether the voter is returning their first mail ballot or initiating the ballot cure process, it is important that either is done in a timely manner. Otherwise, the voter’s mail ballot may be delayed and potentially not counted at all.

A voter may also choose to return their mail ballot to locations designated by the local Board of Elections during voting hours to avoid transit delays, such as an Early Voting Center or at an Early Voting or Election Day polling place. A Chief Judge will have a secure bag for mail ballots and a log sheet available. Alternatively, the voter may “surrender” their mail ballot and cast a provisional ballot on voting equipment instead, which would be presented to the county Board of Canvassers after Election Day.
Mailing the Ballot Assessment

units.prompt: A voter calls their local Board of Elections to request a replacement mail ballot. Which of the following is done to prevent the first mail ballot from being counted instead of the replacement mail ballot?

choices.text: The first mail ballot is found so it can be destroyed.
The replacement mail ballot is created with a newly generated bar code.
A copy of the first mail ballot is made.
The voter must go to their local polling place to make sure the first mail ballot is not counted.

units.prompt: When should a mail ballot be returned through the mail?

choices.text: On Election Day.
After Election Day.
On the voter’s birthday.
As soon as possible.

units.text: In this section, we will discuss the possible physical threats that may need to be mitigated to secure the mail-in voting process after voters return their completed mail ballots to their local Board of Elections.
After a local Board of Elections receives mail ballots, these are then kept in a secure area, such as in election offices or storage facilities.
The following are physical threats related to storage security:

items: An individual gains access to ballot storage and manipulates or destroys ballots.
An individual gains access to a mail room, post office, breaks in, and manipulates or destroys ballots.

units.text: Mail ballots may arrive between weeks before Election Day or after Election Day. Those that are received earlier in the election process will remain in their storage unit until it is time for them to be counted. This makes it important to maintain sufficient security measures during this period of time.

How ballots are stored differs between districts, but some considerations in storage procedures include limiting accessibility to storage areas to a small number of trusted individuals and keeping storage units physically secure with locks. Some districts might require that the whereabouts of ballots are tracked by having office staff and other workers log whenever they move them and why they did so. Knowing who has accessed ballots before, during, and after an election can help identify possible inconsistencies in how they have been handled.
Storage Security Assessment

units.prompt: Before mail ballots are counted, what is a possible area where they can be stored?

choices.text: Pictures of mail ballots are taken and stored on a computer hard drive.
An election staff member’s house
In a public and widely accessible area.
An election office.

units.prompt: How can a storage area be kept physically secure?

choices.text: Any staff member should be allowed to enter a storage area after a breach takes place.
Extra keys for the storage area or unit should be kept somewhere nearby.
Accessibility to storage areas should be limited to a small number of trusted individuals.
All of the above.

units.text: In this section, we will discuss possible insider (human) threats from voters that may need to be mitigated to secure the mail-in voting process.

Insider threats are more likely to happen in mail-in voting due to the nature of the process. Because mail-in voting does not take place in person, communication between Election Officials and voters is more challenging and there are more opportunities for misunderstanding. Mistakes can be made without the intention of harming the process and errors can potentially delay the counting of a voter’s ballot or even cause their ballot to not be counted at all.
Election Judges cannot directly mitigate many insider threats, but it is still important to be aware of them.
The following are insider threats that may arise from voters:

items: A voter may have incorrectly marked their ballot due to misunderstanding or not knowing how to do it or made a mistake while doing so.
A voter may not have signed their ballot correctly or penned a signature that does not match what is on record.
A voter may have an expired identification card.
A voter may not understand the mail-in voting process, have trouble contacting Election Officials, or receive and/or incorrect instructions after contacting Election Officials.

units.text: Voters should be able to have access to the necessary information that will help them cast their ballot. Some examples of what voters need to know include how to fill out their ballot, how to package their ballot, what the deadlines are for sending in their ballot, and what valid forms of ID are if it is needed. It is the responsibility of Election Officials to provide accurate answers to questions asked over phone or email.
Voters Assessment

units.prompt: What is the main reason behind most insider threats in mail-in voting?

choices.text: Voters and Election Officials do not see each other face to face during the process.
Voters must supply their own envelopes to return their ballots.
Voters who use mail-in voting are lazier than voters who vote in person.
Voters do not use electronic voting machines to cast their votes.

units.prompt: What can election staff do to help voters who ask questions about the mail-in voting process?

choices.text: Election staff should be well-versed in how the mail-in voting process works.
Election staff should make sure to answer questions accurately to ensure there is no confusion.
Both A and B.
Election staff should answer questions incorrectly on purpose.

units.text: In this section, we will discuss possible insider (human) threats that could arise during ballot distribution and/or canvassing that may need to be mitigated to secure the mail-in voting process.

Election staff are in charge of distributing ballots and ballot canvassing. These are not primary duties of Election Judges, but they may be hired to assist canvassing teams on a temporary basis. Ballot canvassing is a public event but mistakes and/or malicious actions may still take place during the process.
Insider threats that may arise prior to the ballot canvassing process include:
An election staff member or judge may mistakenly or intentionally:

items: An election staff member or judge may mistakenly or intentionally distribute faulty ballots to voters.
An election staff member or judge may mistakenly or intentionally distribute mail ballots to the wrong addresses.

units.text: Insider threats that may arise during the ballot canvassing process may include when an election staff member or judge mistakenly misinterpret the rules of the process or intentionally choose not to follow them. Because of this, they may also:

items: Interpret a signature on a ballot as fake when it is not.
Identify a ballot as invalid when it is not and discard it.
Offer unclear instructions to voters who contact them for assistance.

units.text: Additionally, prior to, or during the ballot canvassing process, a collaboration may be formed among election staff and/or other election workers to gain access to ballots during different stages of the process (placement in ballot storage, removal from envelopes, counting, duplication, recounting, auditing, other handling). After gaining access to ballots, the malicious actors may edit the markings on the ballots, remove them, destroy them, or add new ballots.

Election staff and judges can prevent mistakes by paying close attention to the training and instructions provided to them before conducting their duties. Additionally, while election staff and judges are completing their duties, they should monitor their peers for suspicious activity, such as physically modifying ballots or misplacing ballots when they are not supposed to. Some states, such as in Maryland, require workers of opposite parties to perform these tasks together as well. Malicious collaborations to interfere with the process can be directly and immediately prevented after misbehavior is witnessed. Cameras are also present to monitor workers.
Ballot Distribution and Canvassing Assessment

units.prompt: What role does an Election Judge have during the canvassing process?

choices.text: They give out instructions to their other team members.
They may be asked to serve on canvassing teams on a temporary basis.
They distribute mail ballots to all addresses in their district.
They edit markings on mail ballots.

units.prompt: What is a mistake that can be made through not paying attention to training and instructions?

choices.text: Misinterpreting a signature as fake.
Offering the correct answer to a voter who asked a question.
Discarding a ballot that is invalid.
Duplicating a ballot that cannot be read by the voting system.

units.prompt: How are election workers monitored while completing their duties?

choices.text: All election workers should watch their peers in case they exhibit misbehavior.
The ballot canvassing process may be viewed by the public.
Cameras are placed in necessary areas.
All of the above.

units.text: In this section, we will discuss possible insider (human) threats from external actors that may need to be mitigated to secure the mail-in voting process.
Malicious insider threats come from external actors who have the intention of harming the process.
The following are insider threats that may arise from external actors:

items: An individual, such as a family member or peer, can register as a different voter and vote using that person’s mail ballot. Alternatively, an external party can steal a ballot and use it to vote.
An individual can register as a deceased voter and vote using that person’s mail ballot.

An individual may form a collaboration with election staff and/or other election workers to gain access to ballots during different stages of the process (placement in ballot storage, removal from envelopes, counting, duplication, recounting, auditing, other handling). After gaining access to ballots, the malicious actors may edit the markings on the ballots, remove them, destroy them, or add new ballots.

units.text: If a voter discovers that their ballot has been affected through their district’s online portal and/or notification from Election Officials, they can initiate the ballot cure process to request a replacement. Election staff and judges should also monitor their peers for suspicious activity while they are working.
External Actors Assessment

units.prompt: What should a voter do if their mail ballot is stolen, marked, and returned?

choices.text: Mark and return a mail ballot from a someone else who is not going to use it.
Initiate the ballot cure process.
Create a mail ballot on their own so they can mark and return it.
Nothing – the Board of Elections will automatically know when to send a replacement.

units.text: In this section, we will discuss possible cyber threat scenarios that Election Judges may need to mitigate to secure the mail-in voting process.

Mail ballots will be counted with digital scanners. Election equipment is made vulnerable to hacking if it is connected to the Internet during any point of the election, so Election Judges must keep them offline. A hacked digital scanner may cause votes to be read incorrectly.

In the case of a hack, affected election equipment should be taken off the Internet if it is online and should not be used to count any more ballots. Election Judges should immediately notify voters who had their ballot affected by the hack so that they can request a replacement.
Cyber Threats Assessment

units.prompt: Which of the following could happen if a digital scanner is kept online?

choices.text: It can be hacked.
Ballots scanned may have their votes denied.
Ballots scanned may their have their votes counted as different than what is marked.
All of the above.

units.prompt: What should be done immediately if election equipment is hacked?

choices.text: Election Judges should continue to use the equipment.
The remaining ballots that have not been scanned should be hand counted.
Equipment should be taken offline and no longer be used.
Election Judges should try to figure out the source of the hack.
